title: Gazebo Simulation Fundamentals
content:
--- title: "Gazebo Simulation Fundamentals" summary: "An introduction to the Gazebo 3D robotics simulator, a powerful tool for testing and developing robot software without the need for physical hardware." tags: [gazebo, simulation, robotics, ros2] keywords: [gazebo, simulation, robotics, 3d, physics, sensors, ros, sdf, world] learningObjectives: - "Understand the role of a simulator in robotics development." - "Learn the basic components of the Gazebo interface." - "Be able to spawn a robot model in a Gazebo world." prerequisites: ["Robot Modeling"] outcome: "Readers will be able to set up and run a basic simulation in Gazebo." successCriteria: - "Launch Gazebo with a pre-built world." - "Spawn a URDF or SDF model into the simulation." - "Interact with the simulation using the Gazebo GUI." toolsUsed: [Gazebo, ROS 2] relatedConcepts: [simulation, digital-twin, physics-engine, sensor-simulation] --- import Prerequisites from '@site/src/components/Prerequisites'; import LearningObjective from '@site/src/components/LearningObjective'; import Outcome from '@site/src/components/Outcome'; import SuccessCriteria from '@site/src/components/SuccessCriteria'; import Exercise from '@site/src/components/Exercise'; import Checkpoint from '@site/src/components/Checkpoint'; # Chapter 3: Gazebo Simulation Fundamentals This chapter will introduce the Gazebo simulation environment and its fundamental concepts.

You should be familiar with robot modeling concepts (URDF/SDF) and have a basic understanding of ROS 2.
  • Understand the role of a simulator in robotics development.
  • Learn the basic components of the Gazebo interface.
  • Be able to spawn a robot model in a Gazebo world.
 ## Why Simulation is Essential Developing and testing on physical robots can be slow, expensive, and risky. A simulator like Gazebo provides a virtual environment where you can safely and rapidly test your robot's software. Gazebo simulates physics, sensors, and actuators, allowing you to develop your code as if it were running on a real robot. ## The Gazebo World A Gazebo simulation takes place in a **world**, which is defined in an SDF file. The world file specifies the environment, including: - **Models:** Robots, furniture, and other objects. - **Physics:** Gravity, friction, and other physical properties. - **Lighting:** Light sources to illuminate the scene. - **Sensors:** Simulated cameras, LiDAR, IMUs, etc. ```mermaid graph TD A(World.sdf) --> B{Physics Engine}; A --> C{Models}; C --> D(Robot 1); C --> E(Table); A --> F{Lighting}; A --> G{Sensors}; ``` ## Interfacing with ROS 2 Gazebo integrates seamlessly with ROS 2 through a set of plugins. These plugins expose the simulator's functionality through standard ROS 2 topics, services, and actions. For example, you can control a simulated robot's joints by publishing messages to a ROS 2 topic, and you can receive simulated sensor data from another topic.

What is a "world" file in Gazebo, and what does it typically define?

Launch an empty Gazebo world. Use the Gazebo GUI to add simple shapes (like a box and a sphere) to the world. Apply different materials and colors to them.

You are now able to create and interact with a basic simulation environment in Gazebo, and you understand how it connects to ROS 2.
  • Launch Gazebo with a pre-built world.
  • Spawn a URDF or SDF model into the simulation.
  • Interact with the simulation using the Gazebo GUI.
